Problem:
Consider a mathematical model that describes the diffusion of a pollutant in a river, represented by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial c}{\\partial t} = D \\frac{\\partial^2 c}{\\partial x^2}\\) where c is the concentration of the pollutant and D is the diffusion coefficient.

If the diffusion coefficient D is increased at time t = 0, will the spread of the pollutant at a downstream location at time T be greater, compared to the scenario where D remains constant?
Explanation: Increasing the diffusion coefficient D enhances the rate at which the pollutant spreads out. Thus, at any fixed downstream location, the concentration of the pollutant will reach earlier and potentially in higher amounts at time T when compared to a constant diffusion scenario.
